Award.AwardTitle: Active Regulation of Thermal Boundary Conductance

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-1402845
Kieffer (Univ. of Michigan, Ann Arbor)


Molecular-scale simulations have shown that when applying an electric field to an electro-active polymer it causes it to constrict and it becomes mechanically stiffer. As a result, the thermal conductivity of the polymer increases by up to 40%. Similarly, when the polymer adheres to a metallic substrate, which serves to apply the field, the adhesive forces are intensified and simulations predict that the heat conductance across this interface increases by a factor of six. Accordingly, one can devise a heat valve by sandwiching a thin electro-active polymer film between two metallic films, and by applying a few tens of volts to these metal films, depending on film thickness, one can turn alter the heat flow rate across this multi-layered structure by a factor of three to four. The objective of this project is to demonstrate this heat flow switching mechanism experimentally, to clearly elucidate the underlying physical principles, and based on these insights, to improve the materials design, for example by creating nano-porous structures of molecularly bonded polymer and ceramic components that exhibit larger deformation amplitudes, so as to achieve bigger heat flow amplification ratios. The expected outcome of this research is a technology with application in numerous situations that require thermal management, including regulating heat flow in confined environments, e.g., living organisms, engines, fuel cells, sensors, and chemical reactors, and even thermal diodes, i.e., devices that allow one to control the direction of heat flow. The research findings may inspire technologies such as actuated membranes for controlled selective filtering, sensors with time-differential sampling capability, deployable medical devices for targeted drug and heat delivery, e.g., for localized cancer treatment. Finally, the research strategy employed here may impact science and technology beyond a specific discipline by validating an emerging research simulation-guided approach and by demonstrating an innovative materials development approach.

The goal of this research is to explore novel nano-structural materials designs that allow for the in situ regulation of thermal transport properties at interfaces and surfaces, i.e., switching between extreme levels of heat transfer or continuously adjusting the thermal conductance within that range. This functional response is achieved by optimizing the structure and topology of electro-active polymers incorporated into dense and nano-porous hybrid materials, i.e., in which the organic and inorganic components are dispersed at the molecular level and chemically bonded to one another, so as to make most efficient use of their inherent properties. To accomplish this goal computation is used to explore the fundamental principles that govern materials behavior and determine the most effective molecular configurations for the targeted functional response. The design principles so obtained guide materials development and appropriate chemical synthesis routes, and are validated by characterizing the dielectric, mechanical, and thermal transport behavior of the resulting materials. First, the underling materials design concepts, which ensues from a molecular simulation-based proof-of-concept study, predicting a 40% thermal conductivity and a six-fold thermal boundary conductance increase when applying an electric field to an ultra-thin layer of piezoelectric polymer deposited on a metal substrate, is verified experimentally and the underlying mechanisms are identified. From these insights, blueprints for the design of materials design that yields maximal thermal transport regulating behavior are derived. Accordingly, nano-porous polymer-inorganic hybrid materials are explored as materials that potentially yield magnified changes in thermal transport properties because of their large strains in response to piezoelectric actuation. Conversely, large-amplitude actuation in purposely designed nano-porous structures are investigated for application as adjustable membranes for selective filtration, detection of pathogens, time-selective sampling, targeted drug delivery, and fluid flow regulation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview --- The objective of this research has been to explore novel nano-structural materials designs that allow for the in situregulation of thermal transport properties at interfaces and surfaces, i.e., switching between extreme levels of heat transfer or continuously adjusting the thermal conductance within that range.  This functionality is achieved by sandwiching an electro-active polymer, e.g., polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) film in between two electrically conducting materials. PVDF serves both as actuator and structurally responsive material. This design concept is based on predictive molecular dynamics simulations and the goal of this project is to verify it experimentally.

Intellectual Merit --- The predictive simulations revealed that the regulation of thermal transport results from two compounding mechanisms: (i) straining of PVDF within the elastic regime results in a change of its elastic modulus (increase upon compression, decrease upon tension), where the strain is induced by applying an electric field and the elastic modulus affects the thermal conductivity within this material, and (ii) the charge polarization in PVDF upon applying an electric field raises the adhesive forces with the materials it is in contact with, resulting in an increased thermal boundary conductance. The first mechanism is predicted to yield changes in heat transfer rates of about 40%, while the second mechanism can result in a three- to six-fold change.

We were able to experimentally verify the first one of these mechanisms, although it turned out to be more complex than expected based on the predictions. Initially, the mechanism eluded us and we feared that we may have overlooked the structural relaxation that takes place in PVDF after applying the electrostatic constraint on a time scale that is not accessible to the MD simulations. However, upon careful experimentation the expected phenomenon became evident. Upon applying a load, the modulus initially changes by 60-70%, and during stress relaxation in it reaches an asymptotic value that differs by about 40-45% from that of the unstrained sample.  Upon releasing the strain, the modulus returns to pre-strain values.  Hence, this mechanism is confirmed to be practically applicable for heat flow regulation.

The important aspect from a fundamental point of view is that the observed behavior deviates from that described by current models of linear visco-elasticity in that (i) the initial slope of the stress-strain curve is much smaller than the adiabatic modulus, which we know from Brillouin light scattering measurements; and (ii) upon stress-relaxation the modulus derived from TT does not recover to the value measured at the beginning of the straining phase, which accounts for the validity of the first heat transport regulation mechanism. These findings prompted the development of an improved model for visco-elasticity for chain-like polymers, casting the phenomenological description into a molecularly resolved perspective and incorporating formalisms of reaction kinetics.

Verification of the second heat transport regulation mechanism is still a work in progress.

Broader impacts --- Two graduate students, one postdoctoral researcher, seven undergraduate students, and one visiting student have been trained in the ways of conducting scientific research, reviewing the scientific literature critically, analytical and creative thinking, and the systematic pursuit of scientific discovery. The students and postdoctoral researchers have developed a range of experimental and computational skills.

We participated in the conception and organization of the Materials Camp for high school teachers, sponsored by the ASM International Foundation, which is held every summer at the University of Michigan Ann Arbor campus since 2002. Typically, 20 high school teachers from across the nation partake in this camp and learn about materials science and engineering in order to convey information about this field to their students. We are also now launching a MS-to-PhD bridge program for minority students from HBCU and HSI that have graduate programs ending with M.S. degrees, specifically in the area of computational science and engineering. Finally, we provided research opportunities for local high school students so to foster their interests in predictive materials development and relate the importance of computational material science.
